div.p:
Hic quaeritur si caritas
Lombardus, I, c. 17, c. 5, n. 1 . This is the second principal part of distinction 17 which thus continues the first part because after the Master posited his intention about the love of God and neighbor, now he shows how it [charity] receives increase or intention within us.

And this part is divided into three because in the first place the Master regarding this introduces the critical question, in the second place hi posits the proper response, and in the third place he adds a different confirmation. The second begins at
his itaque Lombardus, I, c. 17, c. 5, n. 5
etc. The third begins at
ut autem certius Lombardus, I, c. 17, c. 5, n. 8
etc.
Whether through the greater virtual perfection of moral goodness in the pilgrim we are able to conclude that there is a gradual intension of created charity in that same pilgrim?

That not because any doing well of a just pilgrim is to act well immeasurably with respect to the species of moral goodness and virtue, therefore no such thing is intended, and as a consequence neither is charity. The consequence is clear because to the unmeasured something greater is not able to be given. The antecedent is proved because to do something meritorious proceeds from the formal power of the Holy Spirit, consequently such an act is an inmeasurable good with respect to the species of moral virtue and moral goodness. This is the argument of
John of Marchia, in distinction 17 of book 1, in article three
Ripa, I, d. 17, a. 3 .

In the second place, if charity were able to be intended gradually, it would follow that that would also be able to remitted gradually. The consequence is clear because just as through the replication of degrees there is a gradual intension, so through the remission of those degrees there is a remission of them. But the falsity of the consequent is proved because this remission occurs either through a mortal or a venial sin. Not the latter because this corrupts the entire charity, and not the second because then the venial sin would punish with an eternal penalty by its own proper ratio, which is against the
Master, in book 2, distinction 42
Lombard, II, d. 42, xx .

In the third place, if charity were intended gradually, then either acquired charity would be the same with the first or different. If the latter, then it follows that the same thing increases and produces itself. If the second, it follows that two habits distinct only in number would be in the same soul, and thus there would be as many loves in man as a man has degrees of love, which does not seem like it should be said. This is confirmed because either this degree would essential to the quality of charity preexisting in goodness or it would be accidental. If the first, then this first form would be prior to the species of the other because charity is in some essential part. If the second, it follows that it does not make one thing in itself with the charity preceding it, and thus it does not increase it.

In opposition, it is argued that the moral goodness of any pilgrim argues from the common law for some degree of charity in the same thing, therefore the greater goodness would argue for greater charity. But now some pilgrim is more perfect and morally better than before, therefore someone now has more charity than before, and this cannot be unless through the gradual intention of charity, therefore the question is true. The antecedent is from the
Apostle First Corinthians 13
by the grace of God I am what I am I Cor 15:10 . Again, the church prays
eternal omnipotent God, give to us an increase of faith, hope, and love
XXX , etc.
.

First conclusion: though the Holy Spirit is not able to form and actuate the created mind immeasurably, nevertheless the Holy
Spirit is the activating formal power and salvation of the just mind. The first part is clear because it is repugnant for the finite and measured to be actuated and formed immeasurably in its own acting. The second part is proved through
Augustine in his book On grace and the free will
who says,
we are formed and created by God in all good works
Augustinus, De gratia et libero arbitrio, xxx . Again, in
sermon 44 on John
Augustinus, XXX . And these words are used in this distinction where it is said that without the Holy Spirit we are not able to love Christ and we are not able to keep his commandments and the less we perceive it to the same degree that power is not able to reach us.

First corollary: the formal actuative power of the Holy Spirit is as intensely in the mind as it intrinsically gives pleasing or charitable being to it. The conclusion and corollary are against
Master Radulphus de Castello in this question or determination
Radulphus De Castello, xxx
where he asks whether naturally good things are able to be rationally proportioned or compared to gratuitiously good things. The corollary is clear because according to
Augustine Augustinus, XXX
the less we perceive the Holy Spirit in us the less we are able to love Christ, and the more we perceive it the more we love, therefore

The second corollary: any action proceeding from the formal power of uncreated charity is a finite act with respect to the degree and species of virtue and moral goodness. This is clear because then the Holy Spirit would not be power in the mind according to greater and lesser degrees, against
Augustine
Augustinus, XXX .

Third corollary: not every act of the created will proceeding from the formal power of uncreated charity with respect species in the being of the mind is infinitely meritorious or attributable to the will. This is clear because otherwise all meritorious works would be of the same species, which is false. The consequence is clear because all things proceed from the formal power of the Holy Spirit. These two corollaries are from
Iohannis de Rippa, in distinction 17, in question 1
Ripa, I, d. 17, q. 1 .

The second conclusion: though no grade of charity is removed from some evil or guilt, nevertheless any created charity is an intensibile and remissible form. The first part is proved because guild does not diminish charity according to the second introduced against the opposition. The second part is proved because any created charity is divisible in degrees, therefore it is intensible and remissible through some power. The antecedent is clear because neither a maximum nor minimum degree of charity should be given. And the consequence is clear since God is able at once and successively to produce or corrupt any form having and intensive latitude. But it is not the case for us that God produces it in the soul whether at once or successively, as
Gregory says, in distinction 17, article 4
Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 17, a. 4 .

The first corollary: the fervor of any created charity is not reduced through committing or the replication of a venial sin, against
Gregorium in distinctione ista
Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 17, xxx
and against
Henry of Ghent, 5 quodlibet, question 24
Henricus Gandavensis, Quodlibet 5, q. 24, xxx . The corollary is proved because just as intension is in a corporeal quality, so fervor is in charity. But the intension of a quality is not distinguished from the quality, though through a comparison of the extremes it is in some way varied, therefore neither is the fervor of charity distinguished from charity itself. But according to the conclusion no degree of charity is diminished through a venial sin, therefore neither is the fervor diminished.

The second corollary: infused charity is not only diminished by the indolence of the mind, against
Climenton in his theological questions, question 2
Ricardus Kilvington, xxx . The corollary is proved because venial guilt is compossible with charity and does not reduce charity, therefore neither does indolence which is clear a fortiori.

The third corollary: thought charity is not actually diminished from the gratuitous acceptance and conservation of God, this is nevertheless able to be diminished from its own proper and intrinsic ratio. This is clear because this is able to be intensified and diminished, as the conclusion says, therefore if it were dissovled of its own proper nature, it would be diminished by its own contrary, but the sin is the
poison of charity Augustine, 83 Quaestiones, q. 36, c. 1 , according to Augustinum, 83 questions, question 36 .

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
Third conclusion: without the intension or remission of created charity
it stands that the pilgrim is better and more perfect than moral perfection, otherwise the conclusion would be posited that without a new grade or the abjection in the mind of the pilgrim it stands that charity would be intended and the pilgrim would be better now than before. The conclusion is proved because the Holy Spirit with any charity is able to incline the mind equally to inhering in God with love more firmly and for doing well meritoriously, therefore. The antecedent is clear because it is just as easy for the Holy Spirit to concur and to produce with a weak and diminished second cause as it is with an intensified and great second cause. The consequence is clear because that the mind loves God fervently is improve the pilgrim and for charity to be intensified. This conclusion
Lord Giles, in distinction 17 Giles of Rome, I, d. 17, xxx
seems to prove as well as in
Quodlibet 2, question 14 Aegidius Romanus, Quodlibet II, q. 14, xxx , where he shows that when love is intensified, the essence of love with respect to its essentila grade does not change. Nevertheless I do not wish to say that the intension of charity thus occurs de facto but from the possible.

The first corollary: with respect to the remission of cupidity the intension of created charity should not be quantified. This is clear from the conclusion, against
Hugolinus, in distinction 17
Hugolinus, I, d. 17 . This is confirmed because the charity of the glorious virgin would not have been intensified, which is absolutely false. The consequence is clear because she did not have cupidity which would be able to diminish or in contrast which is would be able to increase.

Second corollary: it is the case that one does not stand apart from another from love of the world or from sin and the same one has in himself greater love or better charitable operation, against
the same one in the same place
Hugolinus, I, d. 17, XXX . This is clear through the conclusion.

Third responsive corollary: though de facto greater moral perfection implies a greater charity in the mind or in the will of a just pilgrim, nevertheless without the gradual intension of charity it is the case that the same thing is better now than before from the actuation of immeasurable love or of the highest creator. This is clear because the mind is able to be disposed better and the Holy Spirit is able to be intimated to the mind more fervently without the creation or production of a new grade of charity or grace. It is clear what should be said to the question.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued, if this is true, it would follow that the Holy Spirit would be its form in some mode. The consequent is false because either it would be its essential form or its accidental form. The first is not the case because then it would be its constitutive form, nor the second because nothing is of this type unless it is an accident, but the Holy Spirit is not able to be an accident, therefore. See Radulphus where cited above.

In the second place against the conclusion and the first corollary, it is argued thus because as intensely as the Holy Spirit is able to be formal to itself so would it be as intensely a formal power to the created mind, and thus it would immeasurably absolutely.

In the second place against the second corollary: any act proceeding from a habit in the created and proceeds from the Holy Spirit from the unmeasured volition of the ultimate end with respect to species, therefore the infinite rectitude with respect to species, therefore any such act is of unmeasured virtue.

Against the third corollary: it this kind of acting well were only attributable to a finite created will, it follows that some pure created power will be attributable to it, which is false. The consequences is clear because the formal power of the create Holy Spirit will be able to be intended up to what point is adequate to that power which corresponds to the Holy Spirit from which it is only finite and not immeasurable. The consequent is false.

Against the second conclusion: every evil removes the good, but every sin is evil, therefore sin removes some good and not a natural good, therefore a gratuitious good. The major is clear from the
Enchiridion of Augustine, in chapters 12 and 13
Augustinus, Enchiridion, cc. 12-13 . The minor is known.

In the second place against the first corollary: venial sins make human beings indisposed for eliciting a good work, therefore they reduce the fervor of charity.
The consequence is clear because, if the same fervor remains after the committing an venial sin, then the sinner will operate just as promptly, easily, and delectably as before. This is contrary to experience because a habit is opposed to good things whenever it is generated from repeated venial sins.

In the third place against the second corollary it is argued from scripture,
Ecclesiasticus 19
who condemns small things, falls little by little
Ecclesiasticus 19:1 . Again,
Matthew 24
the charity of many grows cold
Matthew 24:12 . Again,
Chrysostum Homily 3 on Matthew, in the uncompleted work
says:
just as every corporeal artifact is maintained through supervision, so also in the mind virtue is increased through exercise and reduced through desire
Chrysostum, xxx . Again, it follows that man would have to love and to choose to do meritorious work equally with desire just as without. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because desire does not harm one's self nor brings any benefit.

In the fourth place principally against the third corollary through the author of the six principles, because the form is consisting in simple inherence and invariable essence, therefore charity is not remissible from his own nature. The consequence holds because every remission is a variation.

Against the third conclusion, it follows that the same thing would produce itself. The consequence is clear because when charity concurs if it is really the same charity that is acquired was before the intention, it follows that the same charity increases and produces itself. See
Scotus, book 1, distinction 17, in the last question
Scotus, I, d. 17, q. xxx . Again, if charity were able to be intended without stopping, it follows that God would be able to make infinite charity and make it infinitely perfect. The consequent seems value. In the third place, it follows that an entity more perfect than the charity of Christ would be able to be given, against the
Master, in distinction 13 of the third book Lombard, III, d. 13 .

Against the first corollary, it is argued through the saying of
Augustine, in 83 questions, question 36
Augustine, 83 questions, q. 36 , the increase of charity is the decrease of desire, therefore with respect to the advance against desire there is an intention of charity. Again,
Enchiridion 4
says
cupidity lessens while charity grows
Augustinus, Enchiridion, 32, 121 .

Against the second corollary, there is the
Augustine in 83 questions, question 36
where he says,
the venom of charity is the hope gaining and retaining temporal things
Augustine, 83 questions, q. 36, n. 1 , there to whatever degree man is distanced from the love of temporal things, to the same degree is his charitable operation improved, and as a consequence the corollary is false

Against the last corollary, because motion is the acquisition of a part after the part of that to which the thing is moved, therefore without acquisition of a new degree charity is not able to be intended in the mind. The antecedent is from the
Philosopher
Aristotle, Physics, V
and
the Commentator V Physics, comment 48
Averroes, Physics, V, comment 48 .
To the first, the consequence is denied because unchangeable form is able to be causally and supernaturally elevative, as it has been said.
To the second, the consequence is denied because it does not follow that the power of the will is immeasurable, therefore such immeasurable power is a power to an immeasurable will.

To the third, the consequence is denied because, though it proceeds from an immeasurable power and from an immeasurable will, nevertheless this immeasurable volition and immeasurable charity is only in the finite created mind and not immeasurably.
In the second, I say that such acting is not able to be quantified with respect to the fluidity of the uncreated agent, but with respect to all circumstances surrounding such good actions, for it ought to be attended to and named according to the fluidity of the uncreated agent in acting action and not in others one creating action would differ no more than another which one action of God actively taken from another. The consequent is false.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied because they are of a different ratio, therefore whatever created power is intended, it would never reach equality of the other because it would always remain in the latitude of its own species which is below the latitude of another more perfect thing, and similarly to whatever degree the influence of a more perfect agent is diminished, it would never reach to the equality of the inferior.

To the first against the second conclusion, Augustine wished to say that it is said that evil removes either the good which is inside or the good which would be inside if the committing this sin did not commit it, so it is said in what has been proposed because, though a venial sin does not remove or withdraw the good of charity, nevertheless it deprives the mind of some good which it would have if it had not committed it.

But against this it would be able to be objected because as much as a good work is able to bring advantage precisely to the same degree is a sin able to bring obstruction. But some good work brings advantage to a certain degree of charity, therefore some sin is able to be an obstruction by diminishing the a certain degree of charity.

In the second place, because it follows that God would equally love the one sinning and the one not sinning. The consequent seems false. The consequence is proved because from the fact that a venial sin does not diminish charity, it follows that the one sinning venially only is loved by God just as before.

To the first, when it is replied, it is said that, if a comparison is made to demeritorious act and infused habit already in act, then the major is denied, but if the comparison is made with respect to a habit which were acquired, if the work were good, then the major is conceded, but nothing is had against the conclusion.

To the second, it is said, I concede the consequent, indeed perhaps he loves the one sinning more than the one not sinning in the cause in which the one sinning venially has more grace. In the second place, it is said that the consequent is able to understood in two ways. In the first mode thus that the one sinning himself is as pleasing when committing the sin as when not committing the sin, when speaking about an existence that is pleasing according to the eternal law of God, in this way the consequent is conceded. In the second mode that it is equally pleasing or beloved, that is, that it is pleasing to God that he acts in this deformed way just as it is pleasing to God to with old this guilt a, in this way the consequent and the consequence are denied.

To another argument against the first corollary, whatever is concerning ???, the consequence is denied because, though it is the same fervor after committing of venial sins that it was before, nevertheless the one committing is not able in so [to achieve as] intense acts on account of the inclination of cupidity toward the opposite, just as is clear in the object where a greater weight not intensed or diminished, but only for the intension of the lesser weight, the same greater weight is not able to move equally quickly or to lift the lesser weight as before.
In the second place, it would be able to be said that a venial sin indisposes one as much as an added good act disposes better and more, therefore the argument does not conclude.

To that authority
whoever despises small things Ecclesiasticus 19:1
etc. it wishes to say that man from indolence and negligence of doing good work omits many good works which be would do if not for his idleness, and through this something contrary to the corollary does not follow.

To another, the consequence is denied, and when it is said because indolence harms nothing, this is able to be denied because, though a sinner does not diminish charity, nevertheless it impedes the multiplication of works because more meritorious works would be done if there were not this indolence, as is said in the preceding solution. In the second place, it is said and said better that something should been fled from or desired always and proportionally according to what hurts or advantages, for according to
Augustine, XIV, City of God, chapter 13
Augustine, De civitate Dei, XIV, 13, 2
it advantages some to sin, and nevertheless no one ought to desire to sin. He points to the example of Peter. Again, it is not as bad to kill a man and to repent as it is to commit a venial sin and not make satisfaction, and nevertheless the first should not fled less than the second, rather more so.

To that argument which is said form is simple, etc., in the first place Giles would say that the indivisible form would be able to be intended and diminished according to the greater or less participation of that form to the subject. This
Lord Giles says in this distinction Aegidius Romanus, I, d. 17
and in
his Quodlibet, question 14 Giles of Rome, Quodlibet, xxx, 14 . In the second place, it is said that the authority speaks in this place about simplicity opposed to mobile quantity not of perfection, therefore it does not conclude, contra
Scotus, in distinction 17
Scotus, I, d. 17 .

Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem, negatur consequentia. Ad probationem dicitur quod Deus sine motu et sine productione quacumque potest intendere caritatem sicut sibi placet. Secundo dicitur quod dato quod concurreret caritas ad sui intensionem active, non tamen productive quia non omnis est productio quia non omne agens producti aliquid. Tertio dicitur quod non oporteret quod
talis
caritas
concursus terminetur ad aliquam entitatem, sed ad aliqualiter esse ad qualiter non erat prius.
Ad secundum posset concedi, consequens quia aliqua rem esse infinitam non claudit contra dictionem secundum aliquos. Secundo posset negari consequentia.

Ad aliud, negatur consequentia quia dato quod esset maior caritas in anima Petri quam Christi quoad entitatem, non tamen quo ad virtutem et bonitatem seu perfectionem. Ad auctoritatem Augustini dicitur quod minutio cupiditatis est penes intensionem caritatis sed non econverso. Secundo, posset dici quod intendit dicere quod istae sunt causae solum partiales et non totales.

Ad aliam,
83 quaestiones, quaestione Augustinus, 83 quaestiones
dicitur quod caritatis vene??m, licet sit cupiditas, non tamen s?ois sicut est venialis cupiditatis, ideo per talem dtantiam non potest mensurari caritas.

Secundo, posset dici quod non omnis cupiditas est amor temporalium rerum, sicut patet de invidia et blasphemia et multis aliis consimilibus. Ad auctoritatem Philosophi dicitur quod loquitur de motu temporali corporalium, ideo non est ad propositum de caritate. Ad duas p?as rationes in oppositum patet quid dicendum ex dictis.

Ad tertium, potest dici quod illae duae caritates facerent unam unitate aggregationis, sicut daue aequae faciunt unum per se. Item una est unitate compositionis et homogeneitatis, ideo non sequitur quod sicut duo habitus in anima solo numero differentes. Ad confirmationem dicitur quod gradus postquam est acquisitus est sibi essentialis quia talis gradus cum praecedentibus faciunt unam formam per se et constituunt. Et cum dicitur ergo praeexistens caritas, haec consequentia negatur quia nihil requisitum a tali specie in esse prius sibi deficiebat nec prius sibi iste erat essentialis quia non erat etc. sed contra quia sequitur quod ista anima erit simul cara pluribus caritativus, scilicet intensa et remissa et sic erit intense cara et remisse quod patet quia quaelibet forma nata est denominare subiectum, et per consequens gradus intensus et remissus denominabunt subiectum intensum et remissum, hic dicitur negando consequentiam quia licet caritas intensa et remissa non contrarientur, tamen quia remissae carum importat negationem intensae caritatis, ideo simul non potest esse idem carum intensae et remissae et cum dicitur quia quaelibet forma etc. conceditur quod denominabit subiectum sic hoc est tanta caritate carum et tanta etc non autem dicendo hoc est remissae carum.

Hic quaeritur si caritas Lombardus, I, c. 17, c. 5, n. 1
Haec secunda pars distinctionis 17 continet 3 conclusiones. Prima quam ponit Magister quod caritas quae est Spiritus Sanctus in se non proficit nec deficit nec augetur nec minuitur quia immutabilis est in se sed in corde hominis gratia descit.
Secunda conclusio: quod, licet Spiritus Sanctus sit ubique et in omni creatura, tamen non omnis creatura habet ipsum quia aliter bruta et insensibilia ipsum haberent quod non est dicendum.

Tertia conclusio: quod Spiritus Sanctus est caritas quae non habenti datur etiam habenti ut plus habeatur et ut in ipse augeatur et proficiat, et hoc est quando homo in caritate proficit et in merito, et haec sufficiant pro praesenti lectione, sequitur tertia pars huius distinctionis 17.
